Hopkins Is Lagging
Founded eighty-six years ago as the first true "university" in America, The Johns Hopkins University promoted what was then a highly revolutionary concept in
education. We note with disappointment, however, that
the University subsequently, far from being revolutionary, has had difficulty even keeping abreast of
changes in modern educational methods and concepts.
Other universities and colleges, originally taking
their cue from the Hopkins, have forged far ahead of
us. The has been little in the way of experimentation
oi pioneering in teaching methods or programs here
for many years. We should like to make a suggestion or
two—ideas that have been tried on other campuses and
could very well succeed here at Hopkins if initiated on
a not too ambitious scale.
Many universities have a well-integrated "honors"
program for qualified students. Special tutorial systems
provide a unified, interrelating course of study. The
majority of Hopkins students are without advice or
ill-advised as to course selection. A schedule is drawn
up with little in mind except the minimum requirements for graduate school. There should be greater interdependence between courses and more continuity
from year to year. Students shouldn't be left loose to
make haphazard course selections. This is the point
where "freedom" shades off into neglect.
Another highly valuable enterprise would he the
development of an organized "junior year abroad" program. Many far poorer colleges than Hopkins have very
effective and integrated study-abroad systems. A Hopkins student venturing abroad goes blindly down a haphazard road with little idea of what he intends to accomplish in Europe. An experience of this type is of
doubtful educational value.
The introduction of at least make-shift language
laboratories, before the construction of the new library, would be feasible. Such facilities have become
commonplace on all but the poorest of campuses.
The deficiencies are both numerous and obvious.
The above suggestions are hut a few of many badly
needed innovations. They can be done slowly and without great initial expense. It takes only a few people with
the experience and capabilities to carry them out.
The administration of the University certainly realizes where the deficiencies lie. But action is long overdue.

Leadership?
The concept of leadership on this campus has become somewhat distorted. The actions of many of our
so-called "student leaders" are taking a disturbingly
negative and pointless turn.
The current wrangle over the establishment of a
"Gentleman's Code Commrssion" is nothing new to the
Homewood campus. For years our student governments
have exaggerated issues of this nature, intentionally or
unwittingly, as an excuse for avoiding their more fundamental responsibilities to the university and the student
body. As the almost undivided attention of our "student
leaders" goes into this problem, many vital services to
and needs of the students go utterly neglected. With the
use of a little imagination much could be done to better
the lot of the undergraduate student body.
A case in point is the News-Letter's charter bus to
New York City for the Christmas holidays. This is one
type of operation the Student Council could easily promote for the general benefit of the stodents and university staff. But there was little interest. Even ODK,
supposedly the epitome of campus leadership, just couldnot be bothered with the responsibility of sponsoring
such a charter. So the News-Letter, in despair of finding
any campus organizations not preoccupied with the Gentleman's Code Commission, has combined with Dr.
Wickwire's energetic assistants, Keith Payne and Paul
Koons, to sponsor this financially profitless venture into
student service.
But this is only one of countless projects that
might be pursued if our "student leaders" were not so
preoccupied with "leading" and legislating. One of the
few valuable functions the Student Council does perform, sponsorship of the Friday morning lectures, is
now $200 in the red, as we are given to understand.
Moreover, the adverse affect on the prestige of our
two representative councils is obvious. An exaggerated
campaign to devise new and more elegant methods of
conducting student trials is bound to draw bitter resentment from the students. This is especially true when
the campaign is conducted to the exclusion of most
other vital student services.
The regard held for our student leaders atad student government never has been very high here at
Hopkins. This year will certainly nolbe marked by any
noticeable improvement in this lamentable situation.

Hopkins Is Lagging
Founded eighty-six years ago as the first true "university" in America, The Johns Hopkins University promoted what was then a highly revolutionary concept in
education. We note with disappointment, however, that
the University subsequently, far from being revolutionary, has had difficulty even keeping abreast of
changes in modern educational methods and concepts.
Other universities and colleges, originally taking
their cue from the Hopkins, have forged far ahead of
us. The has been little in the way of experimentation
oi pioneering in teaching methods or programs here
for many years. We should like to make a suggestion or
two—ideas that have been tried on other campuses and
could very well succeed here at Hopkins if initiated on
a not too ambitious scale.
Many universities have a well-integrated "honors"
program for qualified students. Special tutorial systems
provide a unified, interrelating course of study. The
majority of Hopkins students are without advice or
ill-advised as to course selection. A schedule is drawn
up with little in mind except the minimum requirements for graduate school. There should be greater interdependence between courses and more continuity
from year to year. Students shouldn't be left loose to
make haphazard course selections. This is the point
where "freedom" shades off into neglect.
Another highly valuable enterprise would he the
development of an organized "junior year abroad" program. Many far poorer colleges than Hopkins have very
effective and integrated study-abroad systems. A Hopkins student venturing abroad goes blindly down a haphazard road with little idea of what he intends to accomplish in Europe. An experience of this type is of
doubtful educational value.
The introduction of at least make-shift language
laboratories, before the construction of the new library, would be feasible. Such facilities have become
commonplace on all but the poorest of campuses.
The deficiencies are both numerous and obvious.
The above suggestions are hut a few of many badly
needed innovations. They can be done slowly and without great initial expense. It takes only a few people with
the experience and capabilities to carry them out.
The administration of the University certainly realizes where the deficiencies lie. But action is long overdue.

Leadership?
The concept of leadership on this campus has become somewhat distorted. The actions of many of our
so-called "student leaders" are taking a disturbingly
negative and pointless turn.
The current wrangle over the establishment of a
"Gentleman's Code Commrssion" is nothing new to the
Homewood campus. For years our student governments
have exaggerated issues of this nature, intentionally or
unwittingly, as an excuse for avoiding their more fundamental responsibilities to the university and the student
body. As the almost undivided attention of our "student
leaders" goes into this problem, many vital services to
and needs of the students go utterly neglected. With the
use of a little imagination much could be done to better
the lot of the undergraduate student body.
A case in point is the News-Letter's charter bus to
New York City for the Christmas holidays. This is one
type of operation the Student Council could easily promote for the general benefit of the stodents and university staff. But there was little interest. Even ODK,

any campus organizations not preoccupied with the Gentleman's Code Commission, has combined with Dr.

preoccupied with "leading" and legislating. One of the

two representative councils is obvious. An exaggerated
campaign to devise new and more elegant methods of
conducting student trials is bound to draw bitter resentment from the students. This is especially true when

other vital student services.

thirty-nine years here.
"We've been pretty fortunate here—no deaths and

third, he collapsed and died.

"On the whole, we can't

a half dozen luxury items
